title: Let It Be
source: Simplified arrangement of the verse section

musicalLanguage.description: One of the most beginner-friendly classic songs ever written. The verse uses just four chords (C-G-Am-F) in the most common pop progression of all time. The gentle tempo and repetitive structure make it ideal for a first 'real song' on piano.
keyMoments: Bars 1-2: C to G — the I-V movement. Simple, open, uplifting.
Bars 3-4: Am to F — the vi-IV movement. This is where the emotion lives.
Bars 5-8: The same progression repeats — lock in the muscle memory.
teachingGoals: Basic chord shapes in root position: C, G, Am, F
Smooth chord transitions without pausing between changes
Simple right-hand melody over left-hand chords
styleTips: Let each chord ring before moving to the next
Right hand melody should float above the chords, soft and vocal

measures.teachingNote: C major — home base. Let the left hand gently arpeggiate while the right sings.
G major — the V chord. Notice how the melody steps down naturally.
A minor — the relative minor. Same notes as C major, different root. Feel the shift.
F major — the IV chord. Let the right hand rest while the left hand carries the harmony.
Back to C — the second time through should feel more confident.
G again — you know this shape now. Focus on the transition from C.
Am — same as bar 3. Your hands should find this automatically now.
F major — hold the final C. You just played the most famous chord progression in pop music.
